abstracts.cdata!:
The Fertilizer Support Project for
            Ethiopia concern to increase the likelihood that crop
            production in 2009-2010 will remain on or near the growth
            trend of recent years. To that end, the development
            objective is to contribute to the Government's efforts
            to ensure aggregate availability of supply of chemical
            fertilizers for the 2009-2010 production seasons adequate to
            meet smallholder farmers' priority demands. On April
            12, 2010 the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development
            notified the Bank that approximately 15 million USD remained
            in the designated account for the Fertilizer Support Project
            and requested that this amount be cancelled and recommitted
            to the Agricultural Growth Project (AGP) and subsequently on
            April 20, 2010 confirmed that all unused funds should be
            cancelled. In a letter dated June 7, 2010 the Government,
            recognizing that there was insufficient time to process the
            reallocation before the AGP financing proposal was due to be
            submitted for consideration by the Board of the World Bank
            Executive Directors, requested that the unused funds be
            instead made available to the Protection of Basic Services
            (PBS) Program Second Phase Project. The value of the balance
            remaining in the designated account of the Ethiopia
            Fertilizer Support Project as of April 12, 2010 when the
            cancellation request was first submitted to the bank is
            equivalent to SDR 10,382,471.90. The recommitment is sought
            by the Government in order to make full use of the remaining
            International Development Association (IDA) resources under
            a different ongoing operation. Since the Fertilizer Support
            Project has been fully implemented and is achieving its
            development objective, the remaining SDR 10,382,471.90
            cannot be used under this project.
